            <script>function neighbourhoodHighlight(params) {
  // console.log("in nieghbourhoodhighlight");
  allNodes = nodes.get({ returnType: "Object" });
  // originalNodes = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(allNodes));
  // if something is selected:
  if (params.nodes.length > 0) {
    highlightActive = true;
    var i, j;
    var selectedNode = params.nodes[0];
    var degrees = 2;

    // mark all nodes as hard to read.
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      // nodeColors[nodeId] = allNodes[nodeId].color;
      allNodes[nodeId].color = "rgba(200,200,200,0.5)";
      if (allNodes[nodeId].hiddenLabel === undefined) {
        allNodes[nodeId].hiddenLabel = allNodes[nodeId].label;
        allNodes[nodeId].label = undefined;
      }
    }
    var connectedNodes = network.getConnectedNodes(selectedNode);
    var allConnectedNodes = [];

    // get the second degree nodes
    for (i = 1; i < degrees; i++) {
      for (j = 0; j < connectedNodes.length; j++) {
        allConnectedNodes = allConnectedNodes.concat(
          network.getConnectedNodes(connectedNodes[j])
        );
      }
    }

    // all second degree nodes get a different color and their label back
    for (i = 0; i < allConnectedNodes.length; i++) {
      // allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].color = "pink";
      allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].color = "rgba(150,150,150,0.75)";
      if (allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel !== undefined) {
        allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].label =
          allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel;
        allNodes[allConnectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel = undefined;
      }
    }

    // all first degree nodes get their own color and their label back
    for (i = 0; i < connectedNodes.length; i++) {
      // allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].color = undefined;
      allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].color = nodeColors[connectedNodes[i]];
      if (allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel !== undefined) {
        allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].label =
          allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel;
        allNodes[connectedNodes[i]].hiddenLabel = undefined;
      }
    }

    // the main node gets its own color and its label back.
    // allNodes[selectedNode].color = undefined;
    allNodes[selectedNode].color = nodeColors[selectedNode];
    if (allNodes[selectedNode].hiddenLabel !== undefined) {
      allNodes[selectedNode].label = allNodes[selectedNode].hiddenLabel;
      allNodes[selectedNode].hiddenLabel = undefined;
    }
  } else if (highlightActive === true) {
    // console.log("highlightActive was true");
    // reset all nodes
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      // allNodes[nodeId].color = "purple";
      allNodes[nodeId].color = nodeColors[nodeId];
      // delete allNodes[nodeId].color;
      if (allNodes[nodeId].hiddenLabel !== undefined) {
        allNodes[nodeId].label = allNodes[nodeId].hiddenLabel;
        allNodes[nodeId].hiddenLabel = undefined;
      }
    }
    highlightActive = false;
  }

  // transform the object into an array
  var updateArray = [];
  if (params.nodes.length > 0) {
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      if (allNodes.hasOwnProperty(nodeId)) {
        // console.log(allNodes[nodeId]);
        updateArray.push(allNodes[nodeId]);
      }
    }
    nodes.update(updateArray);
  } else {
    // console.log("Nothing was selected");
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      if (allNodes.hasOwnProperty(nodeId)) {
        // console.log(allNodes[nodeId]);
        // allNodes[nodeId].color = {};
        updateArray.push(allNodes[nodeId]);
      }
    }
    nodes.update(updateArray);
  }
}

function filterHighlight(params) {
  allNodes = nodes.get({ returnType: "Object" });
  // if something is selected:
  if (params.nodes.length > 0) {
    filterActive = true;
    let selectedNodes = params.nodes;

    // hiding all nodes and saving the label
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      allNodes[nodeId].hidden = true;
      if (allNodes[nodeId].savedLabel === undefined) {
        allNodes[nodeId].savedLabel = allNodes[nodeId].label;
        allNodes[nodeId].label = undefined;
      }
    }

    for (let i=0; i < selectedNodes.length; i++) {
      allNodes[selectedNodes[i]].hidden = false;
      if (allNodes[selectedNodes[i]].savedLabel !== undefined) {
        allNodes[selectedNodes[i]].label = allNodes[selectedNodes[i]].savedLabel;
        allNodes[selectedNodes[i]].savedLabel = undefined;
      }
    }

  } else if (filterActive === true) {
    // reset all nodes
    for (let nodeId in allNodes) {
      allNodes[nodeId].hidden = false;
      if (allNodes[nodeId].savedLabel !== undefined) {
        allNodes[nodeId].label = allNodes[nodeId].savedLabel;
        allNodes[nodeId].savedLabel = undefined;
      }
    }
    filterActive = false;
  }

"source_id": "chunk-b1300329d65fbe2fb43da531763d0cc8"}, {"color": "#97c2fc", "created_at": 1756256411, "description": "Premium Pay is an additional form of compensation awarded to employees who work beyond designated hours, as stipulated by various labor laws. This compensation is especially relevant in certain sectors such as seasonal amusement and recreation industries. It is typically calculated at a rate of one and one-half times the employee's regular rate of pay for any hours worked that exceed the standard weekly hours. 

Regulations concerning Premium Pay are enforced in multiple jurisdictions, including Montana, Ohio, and Oregon, ensuring that employees receive fair remuneration for their overtime work. Premium Pay encompasses not only hours worked beyond the standard weekly thresholds but also includes additional remuneration for work performed on Sundays and holidays. By providing this extra compensation, Premium Pay acknowledges and rewards employees for their increased workload and the additional demands of their job responsibilities. It serves as a critical mechanism to ensure fairness and incentivize productivity in the workplace.<SEP>Premium Pay refers to the additional pay rate for hours worked beyond the standard designated hours.", "entity_id": "Premium Pay", "entity_type": "category", "file_path": "unknown_source", "id": "Premium Pay", "label": "Premium Pay", "shape": "dot", "size": 10, "source_id": "chunk-2eb6a6381ce000eada41422438432af7<SEP>chunk-b5db799124519a5d7584e18e90c16bf8<SEP>chunk-b1300329d65fbe2fb43da531763d0cc8<SEP>chunk-dde6435472530a5dc1897d986288fe44<SEP>chunk-f66ea9a4985ab6362091786ba86062f5<SEP>chunk-7c8c56529e8f2d2beb766c2f9b384038<SEP>chunk-a42ef242a1fe49d053bbb0051ba33ea8<SEP>chunk-d5cc463ee46811e5136fdc7f4e377c8c<SEP>chunk-cebdd66ed1ddd58eb1e0bbbe4c4188d1<SEP>chunk-fd2e015e59c7056941e4026e397a8c0d<SEP>chunk-5058b86a2ddf47a8f035f37d56f7f1ae<SEP>chunk-20cbc05e4be232cdcb221efacac5bcf2<SEP>chunk-87784b4d3e09ba0f11394a200abd9024<SEP>chunk-ab74def6861ed5445c9389b24386879b"}, {"color": "#97c2fc", "created_at": 1756256436, "description": "Basic Minimum Rate refers to the specified minimum wage rate of $5.15 per hour applicable in Wyoming.<SEP>The Basic Minimum Rate is defined as the legally established minimum hourly wage applicable to various employers across different states in the United States, with specific amounts varying based on state economic conditions and legislative decisions. Currently, the Basic Minimum Rate is set at $16.66 per hour in Washington. 

Different states have different Basic Minimum Rates; for example, Vermont has established its rate at $14.01 per hour for employers with two or more employees, while Rhode Island and Oregon have rates of $15.00 and $15.05 per hour, respectively. Several states choose to adhere to the federal minimum wage of $7.25 per hour, including North Dakota, North Carolina, Idaho, and Kansas. However, many others have higher rates: New Mexico and Nevada set theirs at $12.00 per hour; Nebraska at $13.50 per hour; and Missouri at $13.75 per hour. Maryland and Delaware maintain their wages at $15.00 per hour, while New Jersey's rate is slightly higher at $15.49 per hour. 

California leads the nation with the highest Basic Minimum Rate of $16.50 per hour, closely followed by Connecticut at $16.35 per hour and Colorado at $14.81 per hour. Other notable rates include Maine at $14.65 per hour, Michigan at $12.48 per hour for employers with two or more employees, Hawaii at $14.00 per hour, and Florida and Alaska at $13.00 per hour. Additionally, South Dakota has a rate of $11.50 per hour, and the District of Columbia boasts the highest minimum wage in the country at $17.95 per hour. Guam's Basic Minimum Rate is $9.25 per hour, while Pennsylvania aligns with the federal minimum at $7.25 per hour. In the Virgin Islands, the Basic Minimum Rate is set at $10.50 per hour, and Virginia's rate stands at $12.41 per hour, which is subject to annual adjustments.

"Tennessee", "shape": "dot", "size": 10, "source_id": "chunk-b0f69a75edc58567e3f22ce351eb3066"}, {"color": "#97c2fc", "created_at": 1756256434, "description": "Minimum Wage Law refers to the legal standards set for the lowest possible earnings that can be paid to employees.<SEP>The Minimum Wage Law is a comprehensive framework of regulations that establishes the lowest permissible pay rates for workers across various states in the United States, ensuring fair compensation and outlining labor standards, including provisions for overtime and premium pay. 

In Vermont, the Minimum Wage Law specifically regulates minimum wage and overtime pay for employees. Virginia's legislation dictates a basic minimum rate of pay for workers set at $12.41 per hour. Similarly, West Virginia's Minimum Wage Law sets a baseline hourly wage and specifies conditions for premium pay and overtime.

Different states exhibit significant variability in their minimum wage rates. For instance, South Dakota's Minimum Wage Law establishes the minimum wage at $11.50 per hour. In contrast, North Dakota and Idaho adhere to the federal minimum wage of $7.25 per hour, a standard also applicable in regions such as the Northern Mariana Islands. Arizona has a higher minimum wage of $14.70 per hour, while Connecticut boasts the highest rate among the mentioned states at $16.35 per hour. 

Arkansas adjusts its minimum wage regulations based on the size of an employer's workforce, underscoring the differing approaches to minimum wage laws across states. States like New Jersey and Missouri include specific requirements for overtime and premium pay in their Minimum Wage Laws, and Michigan enforces particular regulations for employers with two or more employees. Minnesota also aligns its minimum wage with stipulations for premium pay, whereas Mississippi defaults to the federal standard. 

Utah’s Minimum Wage Law maintains a rate of $7.25 per hour but excludes certain types of employment from its coverage, while Tennessee has no state-level Minimum Wage Law and relies on federal guidelines. Notably, New York adopts a differentiated approach with varying pay rates based on regional economic conditions.
